title: Optimal Social Choice Functions: A Utilitarian View
description: Studies distortion for single-winner elections with $m$ candidates.
results: Theorem 3.2: Every randomized social choice function has distortion at least $\sqrt{m}/3$.
Theorem 3.3: There is a randomized scoring function having distortion $O(\sqrt{m}\log^*m)$.
Section 3: There is a randomized scoring function having distortion at most $2\sqrt{mH_m}$, where $H_m = \sum_{i=1}^m 1/i â‰¤ \ln m + 1$.
Theorem 3.4: There is a polytime randomized scoring function with optimal distortion.

Theorem 4.2: When utility functions are drawn IID from a neutral distribution (utilities of an agent may not sum to 1), then the average-case distortion-optimal social choice function is a scoring function.
Corollary 4.5: When utility functions are drawn IID from $[0, 1]^m$, then the average-case distortion-optimal social choice function is a scoring function.

Section 5: Learning-theoretic model: Utilities are drawn IID from some unknown distribution $D$. We have samples from this distribution, using which we want to design optimal social choice functions. Algorithmic and sample-complexity results are given.
